questions.text: A 26-year-old actor came with complaints of being unable to focus on his work. He worked for a short while in various occupations, before deciding he wanted to be an actor. After attending several auditions, he discovered that he was easily distracted, needed help remembering his lines, and even drifted off during reading. Identify the disorder in the given scenario.
questions.solution:
The disorder in the given scenario can be identified as Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.

Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a neuropsychiatric condition affecting children, adolescents, and adults around the world, characterized by a pattern of diminished sustained attention, and increased impulsivity or hyperactivity. They often have significant impairment in academic functioning and social and interpersonal situations.

ADHD was historically believed to be a childhood condition resulting in delayed development of impulse control that would be generally outgrown by adolescence. Over the past few decades, a significant number of adults with ADHD have been found, diagnosed, and given effective treatment. Utah Criteria for Adult Attention-Deficit/ Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) include retrospective diagnosis of ADHD in childhood and evidence of current impairment from ADHD symptoms in adulthood. 

Adults with residual illness exhibit impulsivity and attention deficit symptoms, such as trouble focusing, difficulty organizing and finishing tasks, increased distractibility, and making snap decisions without considering the repercussions. Many individuals with the illness also suffer from a secondary depressive disorder, which is linked to low self-esteem as a result of their diminished performance, which has an impact on social and professional functioning.

A variety of medications and behavioural interventions are used to treat ADHD. The most widely used medications are methylphenidate and atomoxetine. A combination of medication and psychotherapy is more effective than either treatment alone.

Other options: 

Option A: Patients with chronic depression will usually have low mood and loss of interest in general and this does not fit into the given scenario.

Option B: Borderline personality disorder is characterized by extraordinarily unstable affect, mood, behaviour, object relations, and self-image. Instability in affect due to a marked reactivity of mood. It is characterized by repeated suicidal behaviour, unstable interpersonal relationships, prolonged feelings of emptiness, inappropriate, intense anger, or difficulty in controlling anger. 

Option C: Manic disorder is usually seen with grandiosity and other psychotic symptoms that do not fit into the given situation.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient who is on treatment for a mood disorder was brought to the emergency room with severe headache, sweating, and palpitations. She gives a history of the consumption of red wine. On examination, her BP is 200/110mmHg. The drug that the patient was on is unlikely to be _____
questions.solution:
The drug that the patient was on is unlikely to be Mianserin.

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a cheese reaction caused by the reaction between monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAO-I) and tyramine. Mianserin is an atypical antidepressant and not a MAO-I.

Commonly used antidepressants and their classes are as follows:

  • Fluoxetine
  • Fluvoxamine
  • Paroxetine
  • Sertraline
  • Citalopram
Serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors (SNRI)
  • Venlafaxine
  • Desvenlafaxine
  • Duloxetine
  • Milnacipran
Tricyclic antidepressants
  • Amitriptyline
  • Imipramine
  • Nortriptyline
  • Desipramine
  • Amoxapine
Atypical antipsychotics
  • Aripiprazole
  • Olanzapine
  • Quetiapine
  • Risperidone
Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAO)
  • Isocarboxazid
  • Selegiline
  • Phenelzine
  • Moclobemide
Atypical antidepressants
  • Bupropion
  • Trazodone
  • Mirtazapine
  • Mianserin

Tyramine is a sympathomimetic amine. In patients who are on monoamine oxidase inhibitors, the amine does not undergo degradation. Hence, consumption of tyramine-rich foods like cheese, aged meat, red wine, fish, etc, leads to an excessive amount of tyramine in circulation. This further causes the release of large amounts of catecholamines in the adrenergic nerve endings, resulting in hypertension, agitation, diaphoresis, tachycardia, muscle rigidity, and hyperthermia, followed by hypotension and coma.

Patients should be managed symptomatically by cooling, use of antipyretics, fluid administration, etc. This hypertensive crisis is treated with short-acting drugs like phentolamine - a non-selective alpha antagonist that opposes the alpha receptor-mediated vasoconstriction of sympathomimetics.

questions.text: A woman brings her husband to the psychiatry OPD for evaluation. She says that while watching the news, her husband insists that the news reporter is talking about him and there is a hidden message in the news specifically meant for him. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is the delusion of reference.

In the given scenario, the husband firmly believes that the news reporter is talking about him and there is a hidden message in the news for him. Hence, this is a case of delusion of reference.

Delusions are firm, false beliefs that are held despite objective and obvious contradictory proof. Other members of the culture do not share this belief. Patients with delusional disorders usually have non-bizarre delusions, i.e. situations that can happen in real life, such as making an important discovery (grandeur), having an unfaithful partner (Othello syndrome), etc. This should be differentiated from schizophrenia, where patients have bizarre delusions, such as aliens controlling them or having weird creatures around them, etc.

Risk factors for delusional disorders:

  • Increasing age
  • Sensory impairment or isolation
  • Personality features (e.g.unusual interpersonal sensitivity)
  • Positive family history
  • Isolated socially
  • Recent immigration

DSM-5 criteria for diagnosis of delusional disorder:

  • The presence of one (or more) delusions with a duration of 1 month or longer.
  • Criteria for schizophrenia have never been met.
  • Functioning is not markedly impaired, and behaviour is not bizarre or odd.
  • If manic or major depressive episodes have occurred, these have been brief relative to the duration of the delusional periods.
  • Not attributable to substance abuse, another medical condition, or another mental disorder.

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

Related Pearl: Psychotic disorders

questions.text: Which of the following individuals is likely to belong to Cluster B of personality disorders?

choices.text: An adolescent male patient who feels that his neighbours are always spying on him
A female patient with unstable mood, impulsivity and cuts on her forearms
A male patient who chooses to leave the country to settle alone and does not interact with his family or friends
A young adult who collects crystals believing it will prevent him from getting cancer

questions.solution:
A female patient with unstable mood, impulsivity, and cuts on her forearms fits the description of borderline personality disorder, which comes under Cluster B of personality disorders.

Cluster A personality disorders include paranoid, schizoid, and schizotypal personalities.

Cluster B personality disorders include borderline, histrionic, narcissistic, and antisocial personalities.

Cluster C personality disorders include obsessive-compulsive, avoidant, and dependent personalities.

Other options:

Option 1: An adolescent male patient who feels that his neighbours are always spying on him would fit the description of paranoid personality disorder, which comes under Cluster A.

Option 3: A male patient who chooses to leave the country to settle alone and does not interact with his family or friends would fit the description of schizoid personality disorder, which comes under Cluster A.

Option 4: A young adult who collects crystals, believing it will prevent him from getting cancer, would fit the description of schizotypal personality disorder, which comes under Cluster A.

questions.text: You see a patient receive the treatment shown in the image for severe depression. Which of the following medications should be stopped prior to the procedure?
questions.solution:
Clozapine should be stopped prior to the procedure.

The image shows a patient receiving Electroconvulsive therapy. Clozapine is contraindicated prior to Electroconvulsive therapy as it causes the development of late-appearing seizures. 

ECT was introduced as a treatment modality for schizophrenia by Ugo Cerletti. ECT is useful in the treatment of:

  • Severe depression with suicidal risk (most common indication)
  • Treatment-resistant depression
  • Catatonia
  • Obsessive-compulsive disorder
  • Delirium
  • Episodic psychoses, atypical psychoses
  • Medical conditions such as: 
    • Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
    • Hypopituitarism
    • Intractable seizure disorders
    • The on-off phenomenon of Parkinson's disease.

Other medications to be withdrawn before ECT:

  • Benzodiazepines 
  • Clozapine 
  • Buproprion 
  • Theophylline 
  • Reserpine  

Note: Tardive seizure is a rare complication of ECT. These are seizures that occur after the completion of treatment once the patient has regained consciousness. β-lactam antibiotics and ciprofloxacin have been associated with tardive seizures.

Related Pearl: Key points on electroconvulsive therapy

Produces grand mal seizure in an anesthetized patient.

Mechanism of action:

  • Neuroplasticity: Ability of the brain to form and reorganize synaptic connections.
  • Increases levels of Brain-Derived Growth Factor and Vascular Endothelial Growth Factor

Indications:

  • Treatment-resistant depression
  • Severe depression with suicidal risk (most common indication)
  • Depression with psychotic features
  • Depressed suicidal pregnant women
  • Refusal to eat or drink
  • Imminent risk for suicide
  • Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
  • Catatonia and catatonic schizophrenia
  • Severe agitated depression

Electrode placement: Bifrontotemporal, right unilateral.

Anesthetic agent: Methohexital (most common)

Adverse effects:

  • Retrograde amnesia (most common)
  • Partial anterograde amnesia
  • Disorientation
  • Temporary headache

Memory disturbances recover within 1-6 months. Safe in pregnancy. ECT can reverse extrapyramidal symptoms of neuroleptics.

Contraindications: No absolute contraindication (raised intracranial tension is considered as a relative contraindication).

Increased risk of adverse effects in:

  • Severe cardiovascular disease, recent myocardial infarction
  • Space occupying brain lesion
  • Recent stroke, unstable aneurysm

questions.text: A patient with Parkinson's disease is brought by his wife because of recent changes in behaviour. A new medication was started 4 weeks ago. He has been spending money irresponsibly over the last two weeks and recently bought a boat when they don't live near a beach. Which of the following explains his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Therapy with a D2 agonist explains his symptoms.

This patient with Parkinson's disease(PD) is now presenting with impulsivity and behavioural changes 2 weeks after he was started on a new medication, making medication-induced adverse effects the likely aetiology. Ropinirole is a selective D2/D3 receptor agonist. It is used for the treatment of PD in early disease as a monotherapy and as an add-on for Levodopa-Carbidopa. 

Ropinirole can cause multiple behavioral-related adverse effects, including gambling, impulsive shopping, and sexual proclivity. It can also cause increased daytime sleepiness and hallucinations, so these medications should be avoided in the elderly. 

Other Options:

Option A: Adjustment disorder is a diagnosis of exclusion made when symptoms are not explained by any other cause. This patient's symptoms are consistent with D2 agonist side effects.

Option B: Mania is diagnosed when patients have at least 4 of the DIGFAST criteria(Distractibility, Irresponsibility, Grandiosity, Flight of thoughts, Increased Activity, Sleeplessness, Talkativeness) for at least 1 week. He doesn't meet the criteria for a manic episode. 

Option D: Parkinson-induced psychosis can cause hallucinations and delusions, which is not seen in this patient.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought with complaints of erratic behaviour in school and at home. He is unable to sit still in class for more than a few minutes at a time, pushes other children, and never waits for his turn. The parents don't want him to be started on any addictive medication. Which of the following drugs can be used to manage his symptoms?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described above of a child with inattention and hyperactivity points towards a diagnosis of attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). In a child with parental preferences not to start an addictive medication, atomoxetine can be used.   

Pharmacotherapy is the first line of treatment for ADHD. CNS stimulants are the first-choice agents as they have shown the greatest efficacy with mild, tolerable side effects. The CNS stimulants used are dopamine agonists like methylphenidate (Option A), amphetamine salts, and dextroamphetamine (Option C). These medications have a risk of dependence and addiction. Non-stimulant medications used in the treatment of ADHD include atomoxetine (norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor), clonidine, and guanfacine (Alpha agonists). They are preferred in patients with a family history of addiction or patient preference. 

Psychosocial interventions such as academic organization skills remediation, parent training, behaviour modification in the classroom and at home, cognitive-behavioural therapy (CBT), and social skills training are also used as adjuncts to pharmacotherapy.

Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a neuropsychiatric condition characterized by a pattern of diminished attention span and increased impulsivity or hyperactivity. The prefrontal cortex of the brain has been implicated in its aetiology, and dopamine is the main neurotransmitter. 

ADHD can begin during infancy but is usually recognised between 1-3 years of age. ADHD was known as minimal brain dysfunction earlier. The characteristics of children with ADHD, in order of frequency, are

  • Hyperactivity
  • Attention deficit (short attention span, distractibility)
  • Impulsivity (action before thought, abrupt shifts in activity, lack of organisation)
  • Memory and thinking deficits
  • Specific learning disabilities
  • Speech and hearing deficits.

Under DSM-5 criteria, for diagnosis of ADHD, it is necessary for symptoms to be present prior to age 12, persist for at least 6 months, have a negative impact on social, academic, or occupational activities, and be present in two or more settings.

The course of ADHD is variable. The majority of the cases persist into adult life. The hyperactivity may disappear in some cases, but the decreased attention span and impulse-control problems usually persist. Patients with ADHD are vulnerable to developing antisocial behaviour, conduct disorder, substance use disorders, and mood disorders.

Other Options: 

Option D: Benzodiazepines have no role in the management of ADHD.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man complains of an irresistible urge to move his legs, and it interferes with his sleep. He drinks 2 glasses of wine a day and does not smoke. He takes propranolol for social anxiety disorder. What will be the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Alcohol cessation is the most appropriate management for this patient.

The given clinical condition is restless leg syndrome(RLS). Patients with this condition should be advised to make lifestyle modifications first, like alcohol and caffeine cessation, moderate exercise, and sleep hygiene. 

Restless leg syndrome(RLS) is a typical sensory-motor disorder that generally affects the legs during periods of rest and especially sleep. There is an irresistible urge to shake the legs associated with a burning sensation, itching, and cramps of legs. In idiopathic cases, dopaminergic hypofunction is postulated. 

Iron deficiency is closely associated with RLS, so serum ferritin should be checked for all patients who present with this condition. Uremia, folic acid deficiency, and neuropathies can also lead to RLS.

Management:

  • Lifestyle modifications should be advised first to patients, this includes:
    • alcohol cessation
    • caffeine cessation
    • Massaging the affected limbs
    • Hot baths
  • Medications are given to patients with intractable symptoms
    • Gabapentin
    • Dopaminergic agonists like ropinirole and pramipexole
    • Benzodiazepines 

Other options:

Option A: Ropinirole is useful in the management of RLS but should be started only if conservative management fails 

Option C: Riluzole is a benzothiazole derivative that is used in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis. They inhibit glutaminergic transmission.

Option D: Propranolol is not associated with precipitating or relieving the symptoms of restless leg syndrome.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy who has been diagnosed with Tourette's disorder keeps shouting and speaking obscene words and phrases abruptly in the classroom. What is this tic known as?
questions.solution:
The use of obscene words or phrases, seen in this child with Tourette's disorder, is known as Coprolalia.

Coprolalia is a complex vocal tic characterized by the involuntary and repetitive use of obscene or socially unacceptable words or phrases. Mental coprolalia, which is more common in Tourette's disorder than coprolalia, involves the sudden intrusion of obscene words into the patient's mind. Coprolalia can also be seen in some cases of schizophrenia.

Motor and vocal tics are divided into simple and complex types.

Simple motor tics Complex motor tics

Composed of repetitive, rapid contractions of functionally similar muscle groups.

 More purposeful and ritualistic than simple tics.

Examples:

Eye-blinking

Neck-jerking

Shoulder-shrugging

Facial-grimacing

Head shaking

 Examples: 

Grooming behaviours

Smelling of objects

Jumping

Touching behaviors

Echopraxia (imitation of observed behaviour)

Copropraxia (display of obscene gestures)
Simple vocal tics Complex vocal tics
It consists of sounds that do not form words. Repeating words or phrases out of context.
Examples:

Coughing

Throat-clearing

Grunting

Sniffing

Snorting

Barking

 Examples: 

Coprolalia (use of obscene words or phrases)

Palilalia (a person's repeating his or her words)

Echolalia (repetition of the last-heard words of others)

Tourette's syndrome is a neurobehavioral disorder characterised by sudden, rapid, recurrent, non-rhythmic motor movements and vocalizations called tics. The average age of onset of tics is between 4 years and 6 years of age, although the peak age for the severity of tics is between 10 and 12 years. The onset of tics is seen before the age of 18 years, and the tics may wax and wane in frequency. Over half of the children diagnosed with Tourette's syndrome also meet the criteria for attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder(ADHD).

For a diagnosis of Tourette's disorder, based on the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders-5 (DSM-5) criteria, the presence of at least 2 motor tics along with at least 1 vocal tic persisting for a period greater than 12 months is required.

Behavioural interventions like habit reversal, comprehensive behavioural intervention, and exposure and response prevention are the first lines of treatment. Pharmacotherapy must be included in severe cases when they cause social and emotional problems, depression, or isolation. First-line agents are antipsychotics like aripiprazole and risperidone or noradrenergic agents like atomoxetine, clonidine, and guanfacine, which can be used as adjunctive for comorbid ADHD. Alternative treatments are tetrabenazine, topiramate, and tetrahydrocannabinol.

questions.text: A psychotic patient developed voluntary purposeless movements and was once observed to be standing still for hours with waxy flexibility and negativism. Which of the following is likely to worsen her condition?
questions.solution:
Olanzapine is likely to worsen her condition.

The clinical features are suggestive of a catatonic disorder. Antipsychotics like olanzapine can worsen catatonia due to Parkinsonian side effects and can increase the risk for neuroleptic malignant syndrome.

Catatonia is a syndrome characterised by striking behav­ioral abnormalities such as motoric immobility or excite­ment, negativism, echolalia (mimicry of speech), or echopraxia (mimicry of movement).

The clinical picture may include three or more of the following features:

  1. Stupor: Absence of psychomotor activity and not actively relating to the environment.
  2. Catalepsy: Passive induction of a posture held against gravity.
  3. Waxy flexibility: Slight, even resistance to positioning by examiner.
  4. Negativism: Opposition or no response to instructions or external stimuli.
  5. Posturing: Spontaneous and active maintenance of a posture against gravity.
  6. Mannerism: Odd, circumstantial caricature of normal actions.
  7. Stereotypy: Repetitive, abnormally frequent, non-goal-directed movements
  8. Automatic obedience: Commands are followed automatically, irrespective of their nature.
  9. Grimacing
  10. Ambitendency: Due to ambivalence, opposing actions are carried out.
  11. Echopraxia: Mimicking another's movement.
  12. Echolalia: Mimicking another's speech.
  13. Mutism: Very little or no verbal response to instructions or external stimuli.
  14. Verbigeration: Incomprehensible speech.

The catatonic disorder may occur due to:

  • Advanced mood or psychotic illnesses
  • Neurologi­cal disorders (e.g., nonconvulsive status epilepticus and head trauma)
  • Infections (e.g., encephalitis)
  • Metabolic disturbances (e.g., hepatic encephalopathy, hyponatremia, and hypercalcemia)
  • Drugs induced- like corticoste­roids, immunosuppressants, and antipsychotics (i.e., neurolep­tic) agents.

Management: The primary treatment includes:

  • Identifying and treating underlying medical or pharmacological causes. Any offending substances should be removed.
  • Benzodiazepines, especially lorazepam, are effective in improving the symptoms. Zolpidem, a positive allosteric modulator of GABA-A receptors, is a safe and effective treatment alternative
  • Electroconvulsive therapy is the definitive treatment in cases of life-threatening catatonia (if the patient is unable to eat) or if the patient has developed malignant catatonia.

questions.text:
Which of the following findings are seen in conversion disorder?
  1. Hemianesthesia
  2. Echolalia
  3. Astasia-abasia
  4. La belle indifference
  5. Waxy flexibility
questions.solution:
The findings seen in conversion disorder are:

  • Hemianesthesia
  • Astasia-abasia
  • La belle indifference

Conversion disorder is also known as functional neurological symptom disorder or dissociative disorder. It includes acute and temporary loss of motor or sensory function without any underlying neurological disease. Because the onset of such symptoms often coincides with psychological issues such as internal conflict, it was speculated that these issues converted to neurological symptoms.

Conversion disorder can present with symptoms such as

  1. Hemianesthesia- Strict half-body split
  2. Paresis and paralysis
  3. Coma
  4. Aphonia
  5. Intractable sneezing
  6. Syncope
  7. Tunnel vision
  8. One of the gait disturbances that can be seen is astasia-abasia — a wildly ataxic, staggering gait with gross and irregular truncal movements and thrashing and waving arm movements. 
  9. La belle indifference refers to a lack of concern towards the symptoms despite the apparent severity of the disability. Although not pathognomonic of conversion disorder, it is often seen in association with it. 

Patients of conversion disorder achieve primary gain by keeping internal conflicts outside of their awareness. These conflicts manifest as physical symptoms. As a result of being sick, the patients are excused from obligations and receive support that might not otherwise have been available. This is referred to as secondary gain. 

The Catatonic syndrome may present with three or more of the following features:

  1. Stupor: Absence of psychomotor activity and not actively relating to the environment.
  2. Catalepsy: Passive induction of a posture held against gravity.
  3. Waxy flexibility: Slight, even resistance to positioning by examiner.
  4. Mutism: Very little or no verbal response to instructions or external stimuli.
  5. Negativism: Opposition or no response to instructions or external stimuli.
  6. Posturing: Spontaneous and active maintenance of a posture against gravity.
  7. Mannerism: Odd, circumstantial caricature of normal actions.
  8. Stereotypy: Repetitive, abnormally frequent, non-goal-directed movements
  9. Agitation: Not influenced by external stimuli
  10. Grimacing
  11. Echopraxia: Mimicking another's movement.
  12. Echolalia: Mimicking another's speech.

Related Pearl: Conversion Disorder

Conversion disorder: Also called functional neurological symptom disorder.

Common presenting symptoms:

  • Weakness and/or paralysis
  • Non-epileptic seizures
  • Movement disorders
  • Speech or visual impairment like mutism or blindness
  • Swallowing difficulty
  • Sensory disturbances
  • Cognitive symptoms

Diagnostic criteria:

  • Symptoms of altered neurological function-voluntary motor or sensory
  • Often precipitated by a psychological stressor (the temporal relationship between stressor and symptoms is present)
  • Not feigned or intentionally produced (as in factitious disorder or malingering)
  • Findings incompatible with a recognized neurological condition
  • Symptoms cause significant social or occupational impairment

Other important features:

  • Primary gain - Unconscious relief from stress as the focus of the patient shifts to the symptoms.
  • Secondary gain - Attention gained by the patient (from bystanders) as a result of the symptoms.
  • La-belle indifference - refers to an absence of concern towards one’s problem despite severe disability
  • Astasia abasia - Wildly ataxic, staggering gait accompanied by irregular, jerky truncal movements, thrashing and waving arm movements

Management options:

  • First-line: Education and self-help technique
  • Second-line: Cognitive-behavioral therapy
  • Physical therapy for motor symptoms

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient was brought to the EEG room. He was asked to stay awake and relax with his eyes closed. Which of the following waves will be detected in his EEG?
questions.solution:
Alpha rhythm waves will be detected in the EEG in an awake and relaxed patient with his eyes closed.

Sleep is comprised of two distinct physiological states: non-rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep and REM sleep. Stages I to IV make up the NREM sleep with marked lower physiological functions than during wakefulness. During REM sleep, except for eye movement, there is almost a complete loss of skeletal muscle tone. The threshold for arousal from sleep by sensory stimuli is increased during this time. 

Wakefulness: Low-voltage, mixed frequency activity. When eyes are closed, alpha activity is noted. Eye movements and eye blinks are present, with high muscle tonic activity and voluntary movements.

NREM sleep is composed of stages 1 through 4. About 90 minutes after sleep onset, NREM yields to the first REM episode of the night. Non-REM sleep is divided into four stages:

Stage 1: The transition from wakefulness to sleep. EEG shows a low-voltage, mixed-frequency pattern. A theta rhythm (4–7 Hz) is seen during this stage with vertex sharp waves. There are slow eye movements.

Stage 2: Presence of sinusoidal waves called sleep spindles (7–15 Hz) and K complexes, which are negative sharp waves followed by a positive slow wave. There are no eye movements; muscle tone is reduced.

Stage 3: Presence of a high-amplitude delta rhythm (0.5–4 Hz). There is a further reduction in muscle tone and arousal and no eye movements.

Stage 4: A characteristic pattern of rhythmic slow waves, sometimes referred to as slow-wave sleep. While the occurrence of theta and delta rhythms is normal during sleep. No eye movements and low muscle tone.

REM sleep is characterized by an EEG pattern consisting of low-voltage, random, fast activity with sawtooth waves, as well as theta activity and slow alpha waves.

questions.text:
Which of the following are the core symptoms of autism spectrum disorder?
  1. Deficit in nonverbal social interactions
  2. Anxiety when the daily routine is disturbed
  3. Defect in language development
  4. Intellectual disability
  5. Ritualistic behavior
questions.solution:
Deficits in nonverbal communication, anxiety when the daily routine is disrupted, and ritualistic behaviour are core symptoms of autism spectrum disorder.

Intellectual disability and defects in language development may be present in patients with autism spectrum disorder, but they are not core symptoms — that is, the diagnosis of autism spectrum disorder can be made even without them. 

The core symptoms of autism spectrum disorder have been divided as:

Persistent deficits in social communication and social interactions

  • Delayed development of a social smile
  • Poor eye contact
  • Atypical attachment behaviour: may not acknowledge the most influential people in life
  • Deficits in reciprocal social skills and nonverbal communication
  • Unable to gauge the intentions of others, and thus may lack empathy

Restricted, repetitive patterns of behaviour, interests, or activities

  • Restricted exploration while playing
  • Atypical/ritualistic use of toys and objects, such as lining them up
  • Rigid, repetitive routine
  • Anxiety when the fixed routine is disrupted
  • Enjoying spinning and seeing the water flow
  • Stereotypic behavior

A significant number of children with autism spectrum disorder develop handedness later than expected. Some children may also have disturbances in achieving language milestones. 30% of children with autism spectrum disorder also have intellectual disability.

questions.text: While assessing a case of chronic alcoholism, CAGE criteria are used. Which of the following is correct regarding the criteria?

choices.text: It is used as a screening for alcohol problem
It is used to assess the severity of alcohol dependence
Score of 1 or more strongly suggests significant dependence

questions.solution:
The CAGE questionnaire is a 4 question screening for alcohol problems.

  • C - Have you ever felt you ought to cut down on your drinking?
  • A - Have people annoyed you by criticising your drinking?
  • G - Have you ever felt guilty or bad about your drinking?
  • E - Have you ever had a drink first thing in the morning to steady your nerves or get rid of a hangover (eye-opener)?

One 'yes' response raises suspicion of an alcohol use problem, and more than one is a strong indication of abuse or dependence. A score of 1 or more warrants follow-up. A score of 2 or more strongly suggests significant alcohol problems.

Note: The Severity of Alcohol Dependence Questionnaire (SADQ) was developed to assess the severity of alcohol dependence.

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient whose wife died in a car accident a month ago complains of insomnia and decreased appetite for 2 weeks. He has stopped going out to meet his friends as he does not have the energy to get out of the house.  On further conversing, he says he feels guilty and responsible for his wife's death and confirms not having any thoughts of suicide.  What is the diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient suffers from major depressive disorder.

DSM-V criteria for diagnosis of depression:

  1. Depressed mood most of the day
  2. Anhedonia- diminished interest in day-to-day activities
  3. Significant weight loss or weight gain and/or change in appetite.
  4. Insomnia or hypersomnia
  5. Psychomotor agitation or retardation
  6. Fatigue or loss of energy
  7. Feelings of worthlessness or excessive, inappropriate guilt
  8. Diminished ability to think or concentrate, indecisiveness
  9. Recurrent thoughts of death and suicide

At least five out of nine symptoms must be present over two weeks, and one symptom must be depressed mood or anhedonia.

Other options:

Option A: Acute stress disorder is characterised by intrusive symptoms like distressing memories, dreams and flashbacks of the event occurring after death, serious injury, or sexual violation lasting less than one month.

Option B: Adjustment disorder has emotional or behavioural symptoms in response to an identifiable stressor occurring within 3 months of the onset of the stressor and causing significant functional impairment. It is not diagnosed if the criteria for other disorders are met.

Option D: Post-traumatic stress disorder occurs after exposure to intense trauma such as death or injury. It has recurrent distressing memories of the traumatic event(flashbacks), sleep disturbance and dreams related to the traumatic event, and avoidance of stimuli associated with the traumatic event and symptoms lasting more than one month.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of bipolar disorder presents with nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abnormal movements of her hand since the previous night after dinner at a local restaurant. What is the next best step in the management of her current condition?
questions.solution:
This bipolar patient with nausea, vomiting, confusion, agitation, and tremors pointing towards lithium toxicity should first get serum drug levels tested to rule out lithium toxicity. 

Lithium is a mood stabilizer with a very narrow therapeutic index and is the first line of management in bipolar disorder. It decreases the rate of suicide and is also used in depression with inadequate response to monotherapy and cases of recurrent depression.

Lithium has a very narrow therapeutic index of 0.8-1.2 mEq/L. The severity of lithium toxicity is often divided into the following three grades:

Moderate intoxication 2.5-3.5  confusion, agitation, delirium, tachycardia, and hypertonia

Treatment options include gastric lavage and whole bowel irrigation for patients presenting early to the emergency department. Hemodialysis is done for patients demonstrating any signs and symptoms of severe lithium poisoning.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an immature defense mechanism?
questions.solution:
Sublimation is a mature defense mechanism, unlike introjection, regression, and somatization, which are immature defense mechanisms.

Sublimation is a mature defense mechanism. It means to gratify an impulse by changing the end goal from a socially objectionable one to a socially valued one. Sublimation of aggressive impulses generally takes place through games or sports. Sublimation allows instincts to be channelled and not dammed up or diverted. Hence, in sublimation, feelings are acknowledged, modified, and directed toward a socially valued/acceptable goal so that modest instinctual satisfaction is achieved.

Mature defense mechanisms are healthy and adaptive throughout the life cycle. They are socially adaptive and useful in the integration of personal needs and motives, social demands, and interpersonal relations. They can underlie seemingly admirable and virtuous patterns of behaviour.

Other mature defense mechanisms are:

  • Anticipation
  • Humor
  • Altruism
  • Asceticism
  • Suppression

Immature defense mechanisms are usually triggered due to anxieties related to intimacy or its loss. These mechanisms are fairly common in preadolescent years and adult character disorders. Although they are regarded as socially awkward and undesirable, improvement in interpersonal relationships and personal maturity can alleviate it. Some of the immature defense mechanisms are:

Option B. Introjection involves taking up features from the external world and making them a part of oneself. Introjection of a loved object involves internalizing the characteristics of the object to ensure closeness and constant presence of the object in order to reduce the anxiety associated with separation from or loss of the object. Similarly, the introjection of a feared object involves internalizing the aggressive characteristics of the object and using it defensively to have the aggression under their control. Introjection can also take place from a sense of guilt.

Option C. Regression involves a return to a previous stage of development or functioning to avoid the anxieties or hostilities involved in later stages. This reflects a basic tendency to achieve instinctual gratification or to escape instinctual tension by returning to earlier modes and levels of gratification when later and more differentiated modes fail or involve intolerable conflict.

Option D. In somatization, psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms and tend to react to somatic symptoms rather than psychic ones.

Other immature defenses include:

  • Acting out
  • Blocking
  • Hypochondriasis
  • Passive–aggressive behaviour
  • Projection (non-psychotic)
  • Schizoid fantasy

Neurotic Defenses include:

  • Controlling
  • Displacement
  • Exterternalization
  • Inhibition
  • Intellectualization
  • Isolation
  • Rationalization
  • Reaction formation
  • Repression
  • Sexualization

Narcissistic-Psychotic Defenses include Projection, Denial, and Distortion.

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

questions.text: A young man brings his wife to the psychiatrist, saying she has had spells of uncontrollable overeating followed by self-induced vomiting at least 1-2 times every week for the past four months. There is no history of restriction of food intake, and her body mass index is found to be 19 kg/m2.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the given clinical history of binge eating followed by self-induced vomiting, with weight within the normal range, is bulimia nervosa.

Bulimia nervosa is marked by episodes of binge eating in individuals with a morbid fear of being fat. This is followed by compensatory behaviours such as self-induced vomiting, laxative abuse, and the use of enemas. This is done to prevent weight gain. This pattern is seen at least once a week for ≥3 months. It is commonly seen in women. The weight is usually within the normal range. In some cases, the patients are obese or underweight. Sexual activity remains unaffected, unlike anorexia nervosa patients, who are usually not interested in sex.

It can be treated with cognitive-behavioural therapy (CBT) and pharmacotherapy. CBT involves disrupting the cycle of repeated binge eating-purging and changing the patient's beliefs about food, body weight, and body image. Important drugs used in the treatment of bulimia nervosa are fluoxetine, imipramine, desipramine, trazodone, and monoamine oxidase inhibitors.

Other options:

Option A: Anorexia nervosa is diagnosed by the presence of restriction of food intake that leads to significantly low body weight. Intense fear of gaining weight or persistent behaviour that interferes with weight gain is seen.

Option C: Avoidant food intake disorder is commonly seen in infancy or early childhood. It is characterized by a lack of interest in eating food. This is based on the sensory features of food or the perceived consequences of eating. The patients have significant nutritional deficiencies.

Option D: Binge eating disorder is characterized by recurrent episodes of binge eating without the recurrent use of compensatory behaviours.

questions.text: A female patient presents with repeated episodes of slashing her wrists and attempted suicide. She also has a history of unstable interpersonal relationships, impulsive decision taking, and intense episodic dysphoria. There is no history of depression. Which of the following is the psychotherapy of choice?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of borderline personality disorder. The psychotherapy of choice in this condition is dialectical behaviour therapy (DBT). 

A borderline personality disorder is characterized by extraordinarily unstable affect, mood, behaviour, object relations, and self-image. According to DSM-5, a diagnosis of borderline personality disorder can be made if at least 5 out of the following are shown by the patient:

  • Panicky efforts to avoid real or imagined abandonment
  • Unstable interpersonal relationships
  • Marked and persistently unstable self-image or sense of self
  • Impulsivity in at least two areas of potentially self-damaging like sex, substance abuse, reckless driving, binge eating, etc.
  • Repeated suicidal behaviour, gestures, threats, or self-mutilating behaviour
  • Instability in affect due to a marked reactivity of mood
  • Prolonged feeling of emptiness
  • Inappropriate, intense anger or difficulty in controlling anger
  • Transient stress-related paranoid ideation

DBT is currently the only empirically supported treatment for borderline personality disorder and is particularly effective for those with parasuicidal behaviour, such as frequent cutting.

Patients are seen weekly to improve interpersonal skills and to decrease self-destructive behaviour by using techniques involving advice, metaphor, storytelling, and confrontation.

DBT is influenced by the philosophical perspective of dialectics: "balancing opposites." It helps the individual find ways to hold two seemingly opposite perspectives at once, thereby promoting balance and avoiding the all-or-nothing style of thinking.

Other modalities of treatment include:

  • Mentalization-based treatment
  • Transference-focused psychotherapy
  • Drugs such as antipsychotics, antidepressants (SSRI, TCA), and mood-stabilizing drugs

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presents with severe anhedonia, early morning awakening, weight loss, and profound feelings of guilt over trivial events. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presentations of severe anhedonia, early morning awakening, weight loss, and profound feelings of guilt over trivial events are suggestive of melancholic depression. 

Melancholic depression:

  • Characterized by severe anhedonia, early morning awakening, weight loss, and profound feelings of guilt over trivial events.
  • Often referred to as endogenous depression or depression arising in the absence of stressors.
  • Patients may often have a suicidal tendency.
  • Treatment is with SNRI antidepressants.

Other options

Option B: Atypical depression

  • Characterized by mood reactivity (brightening of the mood in response to positive events), significant weight gain, or increase in appetite, hypersomnia, leaden paralysis (heavy, leaden feelings in the limbs), interpersonal rejection sensitivity resulting in sig­nificant social or occupational impairment
  • Treatment is with MAOIs or SSRIs with bupropion 

Option C: Catatonic depression

  • It is an episode of depression with catatonic features (waxy flexibility, negativism, mutism, posturing) 

Option D: Seasonal depression

  • Presence of regular depressive episodes during a particular season, most commonly during winter
  • May also be known as Seasonal affective disorder
  • Patients respond to phototherapy/light therapy

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presented with low mood, increased appetite, excessive sleep, and a heavy feeling in his arms and legs for the past 3 weeks. Which among the following is the preferred drug in this case?
questions.solution:
The presentations of low mood, increased appetite, excessive sleep, and a heavy feeling in his arms and legs (Leaden paralysis) for the past 3 weeks are suggestive of atypical depression. Phenelzine is the preferred drug among the given options in atypical depression.

Atypical depression is marked by a depressed mood that is associated with weight gain instead of weight loss and with hypersomnia instead of insomnia. MAO inhibitors are the drug of choice in atypical depression. Phenelzine and tranylcypromine are MAO inhibitors. They act by inhibiting monoamine oxidase.

Atypical depression is characterized by:

  • Low mood
  • Increased sleep
  • Increased appetite
  • Weight gain
  • Becomes sensitive to any comments
  • Leaden paralysis

questions.text: Which of the following inherited disorders is most commonly associated with autism spectrum disorder?
questions.solution:
Fragile X syndrome is most commonly associated with autism spectrum disorder (ASD).

Fragile X syndrome is caused by a mutation in the FMR1 gene located on the X chromosome. This mutation results in the loss of function of the fragile X mental retardation protein (FMRP), which is important for normal neural development.

Studies have shown that individuals with Fragile X syndrome have a significantly higher prevalence of autism traits. The symptoms can include social anxiety, communication difficulties, and repetitive behaviours—traits that overlap with those seen in ASD.

Other options:

While Turner syndrome, Down syndrome, and Klinefelter syndrome can all be associated with various developmental and social challenges, Fragile X syndrome is the genetic condition that is most strongly linked to autism spectrum disorder.

Option A: Turner Syndrome is a chromosomal condition that affects females, characterized by the absence of a part or all of a second sex chromosome (45X). Individuals with Turner syndrome may experience social difficulties and learning challenges, the overall association with ASD is weaker compared to Fragile X syndrome. The incidence of autism in Turner syndrome is not as prevalent.

Option B: Down syndrome, also known as trisomy 21, is caused by the presence of an extra chromosome 21. It is characterized by intellectual disability, distinct facial features, and a higher risk of certain medical conditions. Individuals with Down syndrome can exhibit autism-like behaviours, the prevalence of ASD is however lower than that found in individuals with Fragile X syndrome. 

Option D: Klinefelter syndrome occurs in males with an extra X chromosome (47XXY). It can lead to various physical and developmental challenges, including infertility and learning difficulties. There is some evidence to suggest that males with Klinefelter syndrome may have a higher risk of developmental delays and social difficulties. Still, the association with ASD is less clear and not as well established as it is with Fragile X syndrome.

questions.text: Which among the following is true about the diagnostic criteria for schizophrenia?

choices.text: Presence of substance abuse at the time of presentation
Absence of mood disorder during active phase symptoms
Duration of symptoms for less than a month

questions.solution:
According to DSM-5 diagnostic criteria for schizophrenia, the absence of mood disorder during acute-phase symptoms is included in the criteria.

Diagnostic criteria for schizophrenia (DSM-5):

1. The DSM-5 criteria to diagnose schizophrenia require a total duration of 6 months (Option C)

2. Within this 6-months period, there must be at least 1 month of active-phase symptoms (overt psychotic symptoms), where 2 or more of the following have to be present (at least one must be among the i, ii, or iii): 

i) Delusion
ii) Hallucination
iii) Disorganized speech (or formal thought disorder)
iv) Disorganized behaviour
v) Affective flattening or other negative symptoms

3. The rest of the 6-months period may include

  • Continuing psychotic symptoms
  • Prodromal symptoms preceding clear-cut psychosis
  • Residual symptoms after the resolution of the psychotic symptoms

4. Residual symptoms are defined as attenuated forms of psychotic symptoms, such as

  • Odd beliefs
  • Magical thinking
  • Ideas of reference
  • Odd perceptual experiences
  • Peculiar or concrete thinking
  • Vague speech
  • Odd behaviour
  • Negative symptoms may also be included (Option D)

5. Exclusion of mood disorder during active phase symptoms (Option B) & exclusion of substance abuse as well. (Option A)

questions.text:
Which of the following is a true statement about obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD)?

1. The mean age of onset is 20 years
2. Social phobia is a known comorbidity
3. Insight is impaired in most patients
4. Pathological doubt is the most common obsession
questions.solution:
Statements 1,2, i.e. the mean age of onset is 20 years and social phobia is a known comorbidity, are true about obsessive-compulsive disorder.

Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) is a disorder characterised by intrusive thoughts, preoccupations, and compulsions. The mean age of onset is 20 years. Men and women are equally affected.

An obsession is a thought, feeling, or sensation that is repetitive and intrusive. A compulsion is a conscious, recurrent behaviour, e.g., counting or checking, and is done to reduce the anxiety associated with the obsession. The patient might have an obsession, a compulsion, or both. These symptoms cause severe distress to the patient.

Symptom patterns include:

  • Contamination - this is the most common obsession. The patient feels that the objects are contaminated. They repeatedly wash their hands or avoid touching objects which are thought to be contaminated. In extreme cases, patients may rub the skin off their hands due to excessive hand washing or may refuse to leave the house for fear of germs.
  • Pathological doubt - this is the second most common symptom pattern. The patient presents with an obsession with doubt and a compulsion to check. This obsession arises due to possible danger or violence (e.g., forgetting to turn off the stove or not locking a door), which is followed by multiple trips to check, for example, if the stove is turned off if the door is locked, etc.
  • Intrusive thoughts - this is the third most common symptom pattern. These patients have intrusive obsessional thoughts without compulsion. These thoughts could be sexual or an aggressive act that the patient doesn't agree with. The patients might report themselves to the police or confess to a spiritual leader.
  • Symmetry - this is the fourth most common pattern, which can lead to a compulsion of slowness. Patients can take hours to eat a meal or shave their faces.

Most patients are aware of their condition and have preserved insight, while a few patients may have absent insight. The common psychiatric comorbidities in patients with OCD are depression, social phobia, alcohol use disorders, panic, and personality disorders.

Diagnosis of OCD is established when:

  1. There is the presence of obsessions, compulsions or both
  2. Symptoms are time-consuming
  3. Symptoms not related to substance abuse
  4. Symptoms are not better explained by other mental disorders

Management of OCD includes a combination of behavioural therapy and pharmacotherapy:

  • Pharmacotherapy - selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRI) or clomipramine
  • Behavioral therapy - approaches include:
    • Exposure and response prevention
    • Desensitization
    • Thought stopping
    • Flooding
    • Implosion therapy
    • Aversive conditioning

Related Pearl: Obsessive-compulsive disorder

Key points:

  • Most common:
    • Obsession: Contamination
    • Compulsion: Checking, cleaning
  • Treatment: Exposure and Response prevention - 1st line, Cognitive Behavioural Therapy(CBT), CBT with ERP, Pharmacotherapy.
  • Drug of choice: High dose SSRI
  • Treatment in nonresponsive patients: Clomipramine or antipsychotic augmentation
  • Treatment of severe or refractory cases: Deep brain stimulation

questions.text: A woman met with an accident 4 days back in which her child was severely injured. She now has repeated memories, flashbacks, and distressing dreams about the accident. She now tries to avoid the memories and people who were present during the incident. She appears quiet, but there are anger outbursts. She has difficulty sleeping and has an exaggerated startle response. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes acute stress disorder.

Diagnosis of acute stress disorder:

  • A person has exposure to actual or threatened death, serious injury, or sexual violation.
  • Presence of nine or more of the following symptoms
    • Recurrent, involuntary, and intrusive distressing memories 
    • Recurrent distressing dreams related to the event
    • Dissociative reactions (e.g., flashbacks) in which the individual feels or acts as if the traumatic event(s) were recurring.
    • Intense psychological distress
    • Inability to experience happiness, satisfaction, or love feelings
    • An altered sense of the reality of one's surroundings or oneself 
    • Inability to remember an important aspect of the traumatic event
    • Efforts to avoid distressing memories, thoughts
    • Efforts to avoid people, places, or conversations related to the incident
    • Sleep disturbances
    • Irritable behaviour and angry outbursts
    • Hypervigilance
    • Increased startle response
  • The duration of the disturbance is 3 days to 1 month after trauma exposure
  • These disturbances cause significant impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning 
  • The disturbances are not attributable to any medical condition, medications, or alcohol.

Other options:

Option A: In post-traumatic stress disorder, the patient has similar symptoms to an acute stress disorder, but the duration of the disturbance is more than 1 month.

Option B: In adjustment disorder, the patient develops behavioural or emotional symptoms within 3 months of the onset of stressors. The distress is out of proportion to the severity or intensity of the stressor. Once the stressor has been eliminated, the symptoms do not last for more than 6 months. 

Option D: Bereavement is seen immediately or within a few months after the loss of a loved one. Typical signs and symptoms include feelings of sadness, preoccupation with thoughts about the deceased, tearfulness, irritability, insomnia, and difficulties concentrating and carrying out daily activities. It usually lasts for less than 6 months.

questions.text: An elderly man presented with a sad mood, anhedonia, and decreased sleep. He further reports that he believes that everything is coming to an end. He feels his organs are rotting. Additionally, he believes he has a disease that can spread and kill all humans on the planet, and he attempted suicide to prevent this from happening. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette describes a case of Cotard syndrome.

Cotard syndrome or delire de negation or nihilistic delusion disorder: Patients complain that they have lost all their possessions, status, their entire being, and even their internal organs. They also feel that the world has reduced to nothingness. They might believe that they are dead and stop eating. It is commonly seen in patients with severe depression.

Other options:

Option A: In Fregoli Syndrome, the patients have a delusion that the familiar person can assume the appearance of (or disguised as) strangers. 

Option B: In Capgras syndrome (illusion des copies), the patients believe that their family members or other familiar people have been replaced by identical-looking imposters.

Option D: In Othello syndrome, the patient has delusions, which are predominantly jealousy and infidelity involving the spouse. This syndrome is named after the character in Shakespeare's play. 

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

Related Pearl: Disorders of thought and perception

DISORDERS OF THOUGHT

DISORDER OF STREAM OF THOUGHT

(A) Disorder of tempo

(i) Flight of Ideas

Continuous flow of rapid speech that jumps from topic to topic

  • "I like mangoes, the weather is nice, India is great"

(ii) Retardation of thinking

Slow speed of speech and a prolonged latent period before a response

  • "I went to the market (pause)......... the shop was closed"

(iii) Circumstantialities

Inclusion of irrelevant details and going on in a roundabout manner, but their thought ultimately reaches the answer

  • Doctor: "How did you get that bruise?"

  • Patient: "I woke up and had a cup of coffee, read the newspaper and went for a walk. It was a wonderful day in the park. I returned home and watched the TV. I took a nap in the afternoon after lunch. I slipped and fell in the bathroom. The fall gave me this bruise."

(iv) Clang associations

Jumping from one word to another irrelevant rhyming word

  • I am Sam...I like jam...I travel in a tram"

(B) Disorder of continuity

(i) Perseveration

Repetition of out of context words, phrases, or ideas beyond the point of relevance.

  • Q1. What's your name?: "Rahul"

  • Q2. Where are you from?: "Rahul"

  • Q3. How old are you?: "Rahul"

(ii) Thought blocking

A sudden disruption of thought or a break in the flow of ideas

  • "I went to the market (extreme silence)...................."

DISORDER OF FORM OF THOUGHT

(i) Tangentiality

In response to a question, the patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic but does not answer the question exactly. The speech moves away from the actual answer.

  • Doctor: "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?"
  • Patient: "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa"

(ii) Derailment

A breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal-directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.

  • "Some people just don't understand why I had breakfast in America during the first world war"

(iii) Neologisms

Bringing in new words that do not exist.

  • The world is not 'gooder' for people like me"

(iv) Desultory thoughts

Speech is grammatically correct, however, sudden unrelated ideas force their way in from time to time.

  • My actual problem is that the people never understand me and my stomach feels like an empty bucket"

(v) Word salad

Using a mixture of unintelligible meaningless words and sentences

  • Tree bus rain food home car tiger"

DISORDER OF POSSESSION OF THOUGHT
A. Thought alienation

(i) Thought insertion

Thoughts are being inserted into the patient's mind and they recognize them as being foreign and coming from without any stimulus

  • "I have repeated thoughts of killing my neighbors and I believe aliens are putting these ideas into my head at night"

(ii) Thought withdrawal

Delusion that someone or something is removing from one's mind and the patient has no power over this.

  • "Lately, I am losing all my memories and I believe that the 'government agents' are stealing them when I go to sleep"

(iii) Thought broadcasting

Belief that one's thoughts are quietly escaping from one's mind and that other people might be able to access them and hear or see them.

  • "I believe my exact thoughts appear on the TV and the internet and I think I can broadcast them globally" 

(iv) Thought echo

Patient hears the 'echo' of his own thoughts in the form of a voice after he has made the thought.

  • "I thought of making a sandwich in the morning and surprisingly a voice, from nowhere, told me to make a sandwich out loud" 

 B. Obsessions and Compulsions

1. Obsessions

Recurrent and persistent thoughts, impulses. or images that cause distress to oneself.

  • Fear of dirt or contamination
  • Fear of becoming ill
  • Constant thoughts of a certain number
  • Need for symmetry or exactness
  • Worry about whether something has been done "right"
  • Forbidden sexual or religious thoughts

2. Compulsions

Repetitive behaviors or actions that the person feels driven to perform in response to an obsession

  • Washing hands
  • Blinking eyes
  • Counting items, such as currency
  • Checking to see if doors are locked
  • Arranging items in a certain way
  • Requiring constant approval from people around them

 
 DISORDER OF CONTENT OF THOUGHT

(i) Phobias

Persistent fear of an object or situation, typically disproportional to the actual danger posed, in which the sufferer goes to great lengths in avoiding it

  • Arachnophobia - fear of spider
  • Barophobia - fear of gravity
  • Cynophobia - fear of dogs
  • Hemophobia - fear of blood
  • Nosocomephobia - fear of hospitals

(ii) Religious preoccupations

Thoughts involving religious themes or subject matter.

  • "I get instructions from God on how to make my country great"

(iii) Ideas of hopelessness

Thoughts of complete despair where the patient strongly believes that the circumstances will never get better for him.

  • "I am never going to pass my final exams, no matter how hard I study"

(iv) Antisocial urges

Thoughts of indulging in some behaviors or actions that harm or lack consideration for the well being of others.

  • "I have these urges to go rob a bank or blackmail my neighbors for their money"

(v) Delusions

False beliefs that are strongly held and unchangeable in the face of refuting evidence and that are not consistent with the person's educational, social and cultural background.

The three main criteria for a belief to be considered a delusion are:

  • Certainty (held with complete confidence)
  • Incorrigibility (not changeable by proof to the contrary)
  • Impossibility or falsity of content (implausible, bizarre or patently untrue)
 DISORDERS OF PERCEPTIONS

  • Illusion: Misinterpretation of real external stimuli.

  • Hallucination: False sensory perception, externally.

  • Pseudohallucination: False sensory perception from within and having an insight.

  • Depersonalization: Feeling as if one is disconnected from reality, feeling detached from one's own thoughts and one's own physical body.

    "I sometimes drift into a dream-like state where I lose contact with my own self"

  • Derealization: Alteration in the perception or experience of the external world so that it seems unreal.

    "The world and everything around is nothing but just a dream"

questions.text: In which of the following conditions treatment with fluoxetine should be avoided?

choices.text: Depression associated with Bipolar I Disorder

questions.solution:
Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI), and among the given options, it is least suited for the management of hypomania as it may precipitate mania and thus should be avoided.

Fluoxetine is used in the treatment of major depression, obsessive-compulsive disorder, postpartum depression, post-traumatic stress disorder, bulimia and anorexia nervosa, generalised anxiety disorders, panic disorder, and premenstrual dysphoric disorder. It is used as an adjunct with Olanzapine (fixed dose) in the management of bipolar depression type I.

The major adverse effects include sexual dysfunction, dry mouth, urinary retention, insomnia, GI disturbances, and weight gain. It should be avoided in patients recovering from depression with suicidal ideation. This is because fluoxetine improves psychomotor withdrawal, permitting the patient to act on preexisting suicidal impulses as they have more energy.

questions.text: A psychiatry resident asks the patient a certain set of questions using the questionnaire given below. What is he trying to assess?
questions.solution:
The given score is MMSE (Mini Mental Status Examination), which assesses cognitive dysfunction as in dementia. 

MMSE is a 30-point questionnaire from categories including orientation, attention, memory, construction, and language, which tallies up to a score of 30. It is easy to administer and takes less than ten minutes to complete. A score of less than 23 points to cognitive impairment. It was devised by Folstein.

Components:

  • Orientation
  • Registration
  • Attention and calculation
  • Recall
  • Language

It can be used to screen for and assess dementia. Some other screening tools are the Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MOCA), the tablet-based cognitive assessment tool, and the cognistat.

The picture below shows a sample of the MMSE form:

Advantages:

  • Ease of administration and scoring
  • Less time consuming
  • Can be reliably administered and scored by trained clinic staff
  • Can be tolerated even by very low-functioning patients.

Disadvantages:

  • Influenced by the education level of the patient, i.e. highly educated patients with mild Alzheimer's disease may perform very well on the MMSE, whereas healthy individuals with low education may earn scores in the “impaired” range.
  • May not identify mild cognitive defects or deficits associated with noncortical dementias.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to child psychiatry OPD with complaints of repetitive non-verbal gestures for communication. His parents also mention that he prefers to be alone in school always and does not interact with any of his peers. He has very restricted interests in activities. His IQ level, cognitive development, and language skills are normal. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 5-year-old boy with repetitive non-verbal gestures for communication, impaired peer relationships, and restricted interest in activities with a normal IQ and language skills points towards a diagnosis of Asperger syndrome.

Asperger syndrome is an autistic spectrum disorder characterised by a wide range of impairments in social communication and restricted and repetitive behaviours. The aetiology is complex, with genetic and potentially environmental and perinatal contributions. It predominantly affects boys after 3 years of age. It is usually not associated with mental retardation, and a normal IQ, along with competencies in social skills, is considered a good prognostic factor.

Asperger syndrome is characterised by:

  • Impairment in social interaction and development:
    • markedly abnormal nonverbal communicative gestures
    • failure to develop peer relationships at the expected level
  • Restricted interests and patterns of behaviour
  • No significant delay in language, clinically significant cognitive delay, or adaptive impairment

Treatment of Asperger's syndrome involves promoting social communication and peer relationships. Very often, these children are highly verbal and have excellent academic achievement. To help these individuals in social and work settings, self-sufficiency and problem-solving techniques can be utilised.

As per the current updates (DSM-5), autism spectrum disorder (ASD) includes several conditions that are characterized by early onset of severe delay in the development of social and communicative skills and also unusual responses to the environment.

The diagnostic criteria for autism spectrum disorder are as follows:

  1. Persistent deficits in social communication and interaction across multiple contexts
  2. Restricted, repetitive patterns of behaviour, interests, or activities
  3. Symptoms must be present in the early developmental period
  4. Symptoms cause clinically significant impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of social functioning
  5. These disturbances are not better explained by intellectual disability or global developmental delay.

Other options:

Option A: Rett’s syndrome is seen exclusively in girls, where deterioration of developmental milestones, head circumference, and overall growth occurs after 5 months of age. The absence of such a history of deterioration from previous normal development, along with the absence of other characteristic features of Rett's syndrome like- stereotypic motions (eg-hand wringing), poor coordination, ataxia, complete loss of verbal abilities, respiratory difficulties, and seizures makes a diagnosis of Rett syndrome unlikely. 

Options C & D: Heller syndrome/Childhood disintegrative disorder, occurring between the ages of 3–5 years, is characterized by a significant developmental regression after a period of normal development for at least two years. This results in a deterioration of behavioural and adaptive functioning, including self-help skills, with loss of language and social skills, along with stereotyped movements and compulsive behaviour. The absence of these features makes a diagnosis of Childhood disintegrative syndrome unlikely.
