questions.text: A 20-year-old woman was admitted by her parents due to inappropriate behaviour for the past 7 months. In the OPD, she constantly wandered about, pointed aimlessly at her surroundings, burst into laughter without any reason, and made lip-sucking actions. She said that an evil giant was always around her, although no one was near her. Lack of personal care and unorganised behaviour were also noted. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a young woman with inappropriate, bizarre behaviour, aimless activity, presence of delusions, and lack of personal care points towards a diagnosis of schizophrenia, which is likely to be of the hebephrenic or disorganised type.

Hebephrenic schizophrenia (disorganised) has an early onset, generally occurring before 25 years of age. It is characterised by marked regression of behaviour that becomes disorganised and poor contact with reality. Lack of personal care and aimless non-constructive activity is also usually noted. Social behaviour and emotional responses are inappropriate. Sometimes, these patients may burst out laughing or have inappropriate grinning or grimacing behaviour. It has the worst prognosis after simple schizophrenia. 

Schizophrenia is a psychotic disorder with the following criteria: 

1. The DSM-5 criteria to diagnose schizophrenia require a total duration of 6 months.

2. Within these 6 months, there must be at least 1 month of active-phase symptoms (overt psychotic symptoms), where 2 or more of the following have to be present (at least one must be among the a, b, or c): 

  1. Delusion
  2. Hallucination
  3. Disorganized speech (or formal thought disorder)
  4. Disorganized behaviour
  5. Affective flattening or other negative symptoms

3. The rest of the 6 months may include

  • Continuing psychotic symptoms
  • Prodromal symptoms preceding clear-cut psychosis
  • Residual symptoms after the resolution of the psychotic symptoms

4. Residual symptoms are defined as attenuated forms of psychotic symptoms, such as

  • Odd beliefs
  • Magical thinking
  • Ideas of reference
  • Odd perceptual experiences
  • Peculiar or concrete thinking
  • Vague speech
  • Odd behaviour
  • Negative symptoms may also be included

5. Exclusion of mood disorder & substance abuse

Other types of schizophrenia

Paranoid schizophrenia:

  • Most common type.
  • Often called paraphrenia in progressive deterioration. 
  • Usual onset in 3rddecade
  • Characterized by delusions of persecution, grandeur, control, etc.
  • Can be associated with hallucination

Catatonic schizophrenia:

  • Marked disturbance in motor function
  • May involve stupor, negativism, rigidity, excitement, or posturing
  • Alteration between extremes of excitement and stupor
  • Best prognosis
  • Term coined by Kahlbaum

Simple schizophrenia:

  • The primary symptom is withdrawal from social and work-related situations
  • Characterized by a gradual, insidious loss of drive and ambition
  • Do not experience persistent hallucinations or delusions
  • Poor prognosis (simple > hebephrenic)

questions.text: A patient was brought to the emergency room with a suspected opioid overdose. On examination, he had severe respiratory depression. He was intubated and started on mechanical ventilation. What is the drug of choice to be administered to this patient?
questions.solution:
Intravenous naloxone is the drug of choice in acute opioid overdose.

Naloxone is a pure opioid antagonist that reverses all effects of an opioid overdose except sedation. The first step is to ensure an adequate airway. Intubation and mechanical ventilation may be necessary.

Clinically, patients with opioid overdose present with respiratory depression and pinpoint pupils (miosis). On examination, there is hypotension, bradycardia, shallow breathing, and hypothermia.

Intravenous naloxone is administered at a slow rate. Increased respiratory rate and pupillary dilation should occur promptly, which indicates signs of improvement. If there is no response to the initial dosage, repeat the dose after a few minutes. Repeated administration may be required to prevent the recurrence of opioid toxicity because naloxone has a low duration of action.

The FDA approved a higher dose of naloxone hydrochloride nasal spray to treat opioid overdose. The newly approved product delivers 8 mg of naloxone into the nasal cavity. The FDA had previously approved 2 mg and 4 mg naloxone nasal spray products.

Note: Naloxone is contraindicated in infants born to mothers with opiate addiction as it may precipitate acute neonatal withdrawal with seizures.

Other options:

Option B: Flumazenil is the inverse agonist of benzodiazepine receptors and is used for the treatment of benzodiazepine overdose.

Option C: Buprenorphine is a partial opioid agonist. It is used as an analgesic for chronic pain conditions like cancer pain and also used for the treatment of opioid dependence as an alternative to methadone.

Option D: Naltrexone is an opioid antagonist that blocks opioid effects, particularly euphoria, and discourages per­sons with opioid dependence from substance-seeking behaviour. It is not the first choice in acute opioid overdose.

Related Pearl: Pure opioid antagonists

Naloxone: short-acting opioid antagonist with duration of action of 1-2 hours. Used in opioid overdose and respiratory depression in newborns due to perinatal opioid use.

Naltrexone: long-acting opioid antagonist with effects lasting till 48 hours. Used for prevention of relapse in opioid addiction treatment. It is associated with hepatotoxicity. It does not suppress craving in opioid addiction but suppresses craving in chronic alcoholics.

Nalmefene: long-acting opioid antagonist with a half-life of 8-10 hours administered intravenously. Used in opioid overdose like naloxone.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy was brought by his parents with complaints of waking up in the night and screaming for the past 4 months. The episodes were regular at around 10 pm every night, but the boy was not able to recall the episode happening and was inconsolable during the episode. He started going to school 5 months ago and had a liking for violent video games. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above scenario is where a boy who wakes up in the middle of the night screaming and does not recall the event in the morning is experiencing sleep terrors or night terrors.

Sleep terrors/night terrors/pavor noc­turnus/incubus are sleep arousal disorders that are seen in stages 3 and 4 of non-rapid eye movement sleep. They are characterised by recurrent episodes, usually occurring in the first third of the night. The disorder may be familial and is mostly seen in young children and rarely in adults.

Clinical features include:

  • The patient experiences intense fear, characterised by screaming and relative unresponsiveness to the efforts of others to comfort the patient
  • There are autonomic signs like mydriasis, tachycardia, rapid breathing, and sweating during each episode, suggestive of intense fear.
  • There is no memory of the episode, causing confusion and disorientation if awakened.
  • There may be incoherent vocalisations
  • Sleep terrors are usually devoid of any images or may contain only fragments of very brief, frightening static images.
  • There are no signs of temporal lobe epilepsy or other sei­zure disorders

Precipitants of sleep terrors can be:

  • Fever
  • Sleep deprivation
  • CNS depressant withdrawal.
  • History of a traumatic experience
  • Psychiatric issues

Treatment involves:

  • Universal sleep hygiene
  • Behav­ioral techniques
  • Stimu­lus control therapy
  • Lucid dream therapy
  • Cognitive therapy

Nightmare disorder/dream anxiety attacks: Terrifying dreams that occur in the rapid eye movement stage of sleep. They pro­duce sympathetic activation to awaken the patient to wakefulness, where the dream can be recollected. They are commonly seen in young children and adults with post-traumatic stress disorder.

Precipitating factors include:

  • Traumatic events
  • Medications like L-DOPA and beta blockers
  • Withdrawal from REM suppressant medications
  • Drug or alcohol abuse
  • Sleep deprivation

Sleep-related groaning/Catathrenia: Chronic condition characterized by prolonged, frequent loud groans during sleep, which occur at any stage of sleep. It may begin during childhood and is not related to any psychiatric or physiologic abnormalities. There is no known treatment.

Sleep-related hallucinations: Visual images that are difficult to differentiate from dreams, occurring at sleep onset (hypnagogic) or on awakening (hypnopompic) from sleep. They are com­mon in patients with narcolepsy. They usually happen with abrupt awakening and without remembrance of dreaming. The images may be frightening, vivid, immobile and usually disappear when a light is turned on.

questions.text: A young man alleges that his wife has the capability to change herself to the form of other persons. He refuses to be convinced even after being given clear evidence to the contrary. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The delusion that familiar persons can change themselves into other persons at will is known as intermetamorphosis.

Other options:

Option B: Fregoli syndrome is a disorder in which a person holds a delusional belief that different people are a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Option C: Delusion of subjective doubles, also called Doppelganger, is when a person feels he has his own impostor (duplicate).

Option D: The delusion in Capgras syndrome is the belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an imposter.

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man presents for a health check-up, during which the doctor finds that he is reluctant to talk about his illnesses. He is suspicious that the information will be used to harm him. He does not trust his family either for the same reason. He does not forgive easily and bears grudges. What is the type of personality disorder that he has?
questions.solution:
The given history of long-standing suspiciousness, not trusting people, and bearing grudges for insults is suggestive of paranoid personality disorder.

Paranoid personality disorder, a part of cluster A personality disorders, is characterized by pervasive suspiciousness and mistrust in all interpersonal relationships. They are excessively fearful of perceived threats and deceit and often read hidden demeaning or threatening meanings into benign remarks. They are reluctant to confide in others due to the fear that the information they provide will be used against them maliciously.

They tend to be extremely jealous, hostile, argumentative, and defensive. Their paranoia prevents them from establishing any overly involved relationship. They persistently bear grudges and can get irritable and angry easily. They use the defense mechanism of projection by displacing their insecurities on others. 

They may not be willing to accept that they need psychiatric help. Psychotherapy is the treatment of choice. Care should be taken by the therapist to not behave defensively if accused of making a mistake. Pharmacotherapy is generally used to deal with anxiety and agitation. Diazepam is used as an anxiolytic, while antipsychotics like haloperidol or pimozide may be required to deal with agitation.

Other options:

Option A: Individuals with schizoid personality disorder are usually eccentric and isolated. They neither desire nor enjoy close relationships. They always choose to be alone and lack close friends. They are emotionally cold and appear indifferent to praise or criticism.

Option B: Individuals with schizotypal personality disorder appear odd and strange to surrounding people. They have ideas of reference, odd or magical thinking, inappropriate or constricted affect, and suspiciousness.

Option D: Individuals with histrionic personality disorder have excessive emotional and attention-seeking behaviour. They are uncomfortable in situations where they are not the centre of attraction. They also have inappropriate, sexually seductive, or provocative behaviour. They try to use their physical appearance to draw others' attention.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male patient is brought to the psychiatry OPD by his wife. He is convinced that the lead actress of a film he watched recently is deeply in love with him and wants to marry him. She also says that he is socially withdrawn and doesn't have many friends. Upon conducting a mental status examination, there are no other significant findings. What is the most likely diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the man has a false belief that his chairman wants to marry him, which is a delusion of love, also known as de Clérambault syndrome/erotomania /psychose passionelle.

Delusions are false beliefs that are firmly held despite objective and obvious contradictory proof. It can be present in conditions like schizophrenia, mania, major depressive disorders, and delusional disorders. 

The erotomania is more common in women but can be seen in men as well. The patient feels that someone, who is usually of a higher status, is deeply in love with them. Patients with this delusion are usually solitary, withdrawn, dependent, and sexually inhibited. It is usually sudden in onset and runs a chronic course. It is seen in conditions like schizophrenia, mood disorder, and other organic disorders.

Other options: 

Option B: Capgras syndrome is a delusion of misidentification. Here, the patient believes that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double, i.e. an impostor.

Option C: In the delusion of reference, the patient believes that events, objects, or behaviour of others have a special significance to him. For, when he comes across people talking, he might assume that the discussion is about them.

Option D: Othello syndrome is the presence of marked morbid, pathological, or delusional jealousy. The patient here has doubts of infidelity, which is also known as conjugal paranoia. The person holds an abnormal belief that their spouse or partner is being unfaithful.

Related Pearl: Disorders of thought and perception

DISORDERS OF THOUGHT

DISORDER OF STREAM OF THOUGHT

(A) Disorder of tempo

(i) Flight of Ideas

Continuous flow of rapid speech that jumps from topic to topic

  • "I like mangoes, the weather is nice, India is great"

(ii) Retardation of thinking

Slow speed of speech and a prolonged latent period before a response

  • "I went to the market (pause)......... the shop was closed"

(iii) Circumstantialities

Inclusion of irrelevant details and going on in a roundabout manner, but their thought ultimately reaches the answer

  • Doctor: "How did you get that bruise?"

  • Patient: "I woke up and had a cup of coffee, read the newspaper and went for a walk. It was a wonderful day in the park. I returned home and watched the TV. I took a nap in the afternoon after lunch. I slipped and fell in the bathroom. The fall gave me this bruise."

(iv) Clang associations

Jumping from one word to another irrelevant rhyming word

  • I am Sam...I like jam...I travel in a tram"

(B) Disorder of continuity

(i) Perseveration

Repetition of out of context words, phrases, or ideas beyond the point of relevance.

  • Q1. What's your name?: "Rahul"

  • Q2. Where are you from?: "Rahul"

  • Q3. How old are you?: "Rahul"

(ii) Thought blocking

A sudden disruption of thought or a break in the flow of ideas

  • "I went to the market (extreme silence)...................."

DISORDER OF FORM OF THOUGHT

(i) Tangentiality

In response to a question, the patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic but does not answer the question exactly. The speech moves away from the actual answer.

  • Doctor: "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?"
  • Patient: "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa"

(ii) Derailment

A breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal-directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.

  • "Some people just don't understand why I had breakfast in America during the first world war"

(iii) Neologisms

Bringing in new words that do not exist.

  • The world is not 'gooder' for people like me"

(iv) Desultory thoughts

Speech is grammatically correct, however, sudden unrelated ideas force their way in from time to time.

  • My actual problem is that the people never understand me and my stomach feels like an empty bucket"

(v) Word salad

Using a mixture of unintelligible meaningless words and sentences

  • Tree bus rain food home car tiger"

DISORDER OF POSSESSION OF THOUGHT
A. Thought alienation

(i) Thought insertion

Thoughts are being inserted into the patient's mind and they recognize them as being foreign and coming from without any stimulus

  • "I have repeated thoughts of killing my neighbors and I believe aliens are putting these ideas into my head at night"

(ii) Thought withdrawal

Delusion that someone or something is removing from one's mind and the patient has no power over this.

  • "Lately, I am losing all my memories and I believe that the 'government agents' are stealing them when I go to sleep"

(iii) Thought broadcasting

Belief that one's thoughts are quietly escaping from one's mind and that other people might be able to access them and hear or see them.

  • "I believe my exact thoughts appear on the TV and the internet and I think I can broadcast them globally" 

(iv) Thought echo

Patient hears the 'echo' of his own thoughts in the form of a voice after he has made the thought.

  • "I thought of making a sandwich in the morning and surprisingly a voice, from nowhere, told me to make a sandwich out loud" 

 B. Obsessions and Compulsions

1. Obsessions

Recurrent and persistent thoughts, impulses. or images that cause distress to oneself.

  • Fear of dirt or contamination
  • Fear of becoming ill
  • Constant thoughts of a certain number
  • Need for symmetry or exactness
  • Worry about whether something has been done "right"
  • Forbidden sexual or religious thoughts

2. Compulsions

Repetitive behaviors or actions that the person feels driven to perform in response to an obsession

  • Washing hands
  • Blinking eyes
  • Counting items, such as currency
  • Checking to see if doors are locked
  • Arranging items in a certain way
  • Requiring constant approval from people around them

 
 DISORDER OF CONTENT OF THOUGHT

(i) Phobias

Persistent fear of an object or situation, typically disproportional to the actual danger posed, in which the sufferer goes to great lengths in avoiding it

  • Arachnophobia - fear of spider
  • Barophobia - fear of gravity
  • Cynophobia - fear of dogs
  • Hemophobia - fear of blood
  • Nosocomephobia - fear of hospitals

(ii) Religious preoccupations

Thoughts involving religious themes or subject matter.

  • "I get instructions from God on how to make my country great"

(iii) Ideas of hopelessness

Thoughts of complete despair where the patient strongly believes that the circumstances will never get better for him.

  • "I am never going to pass my final exams, no matter how hard I study"

(iv) Antisocial urges

Thoughts of indulging in some behaviors or actions that harm or lack consideration for the well being of others.

  • "I have these urges to go rob a bank or blackmail my neighbors for their money"

(v) Delusions

False beliefs that are strongly held and unchangeable in the face of refuting evidence and that are not consistent with the person's educational, social and cultural background.

The three main criteria for a belief to be considered a delusion are:

  • Certainty (held with complete confidence)
  • Incorrigibility (not changeable by proof to the contrary)
  • Impossibility or falsity of content (implausible, bizarre or patently untrue)
 DISORDERS OF PERCEPTIONS

  • Illusion: Misinterpretation of real external stimuli.

  • Hallucination: False sensory perception, externally.

  • Pseudohallucination: False sensory perception from within and having an insight.

  • Depersonalization: Feeling as if one is disconnected from reality, feeling detached from one's own thoughts and one's own physical body.

    "I sometimes drift into a dream-like state where I lose contact with my own self"

  • Derealization: Alteration in the perception or experience of the external world so that it seems unreal.

    "The world and everything around is nothing but just a dream"

questions.text: During a group therapy session for individuals with anxiety disorders, a participant starts crying uncontrollably and expressing intense fear. Soon, other participants began to display similar symptoms of anxiety, trembling hands, and rapid breathing. This phenomenon is best described as:
questions.solution:
This scenario in which one patient's emotional response triggers similar emotions in other members of a group psychotherapy session is known as contagion.

Contagion occurs when one's expression of emotion stimulates similar emotions in another. It is a phenomenon observed in group psychotherapy. The goal of group psychotherapy is to enhance patients' self-awareness by observing their interactions with other members of the group, who offer feedback about their behaviour. Additionally, it equips patients with better social and interpersonal skills and enhances communication between patients and staff.

Some other therapeutic factors in group psychotherapy include:

  • Altruism: It refers to a phenomenon where a person puts another person's needs before their own needs and finds value in helping others.
  • Imitation: It refers to conscious emulation or modelling of one's behaviour after that of another.
  • Cohesion (Option D): It refers to a sense that the group is working together toward a common goal.
  • Catharsis: It is defined as an expression of ideas, thoughts, and suppressed material that is accompanied by an emotional response that produces a state of relief in the patient.
  • Transference (Option A): Projection of feelings, thoughts, and wishes onto the therapist, who has come to represent an object from the patient's past.
  • Universalization: The awareness of the patient that he or she is not alone in having problems (Option C).
  • Ventilation: It is also known as self-disclosure, where the patient expresses suppressed feelings, ideas, or events to other group members. They share personal secrets that ameliorate a sense of sin or guilt.
  • Identification: An unconscious defense mechanism where one incorporates another person or object's qualities into their ego system.

questions.text: All of the following changes in the patient's behavior suggest an increased risk of suicide, except ______.

choices.text: Patient recovering from a suicidal depression
Patient with a history of multiple suicidal attempts
Sudden peace of mind in patient with depression
Patients with depression having low energy state

questions.solution:
Patients with depression having a low energy state are at a relatively lower risk for suicide. 

Antidepressants like fluoxetine (serotonergic action) may increase the energy state of patients with suicidal depression. This permits the patient to act on preexisting suicidal impulses because they have more energy. Due to this possibility of an association between selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) and suicidal attempts, the FDA has issued a black box warning regarding the use of SSRIs.

In patients recovering from suicidal depression as the depression lifts, the patients become ener­gized and, thus, are able to put their suicidal plans into action. This is known as paradoxical suicide.

Patients with a history of suicidal attempts in the past have a relatively high risk of attempting suicide. Patients with depression who suddenly appear with peacefulness should be suspected of having a secret decision to commit suicide.

questions.text: In the experiment shown below, what role does the whistle play?
questions.solution:
The experiment shown in the image is that of classical conditioning by Ivan Pavlov. The whistle plays the role of a conditional stimulus.

Classical conditioning is the theory of learning where neutral stimuli are associated with psychologically significant events.

Events in the Pavlov experiment:

  • Food - Unconditional stimulus (Option B) as it elicits salivation before the experiment commences
  • Response to food - Salivation as a result of the unconditional stimulus is the unconditional response (Option A) as it is elicited before the commencement of the experiment.
  • Bell/Whistle - Conditional stimulus as it elicits salivation conditional to the pairing of the bell and food
  • Response to the bell/whistle - This is known as the conditional response (Option C) as the dog has been conditioned to react to the conditional stimulus.

This model usually deals with involuntary responses. It is also called learning by association or respondent conditioning. He's also known for his work on the physiology of digestion

questions.text: A 20-year-old man was brought by his father to your clinic with the complaints that he has become very irritable, excessively talkative, and spends around 12 hours playing video games for the past 8 days. However, he attends his online classes regularly. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given symptoms occurring for 8 days, without causing occupational impairment (still attends his online classes regularly) point toward a diagnosis of hypomania. 

Diagnostic criteria for hypomania:

  • A distinct period of persistently elevated/irritable mood, increased energy levels, and activity lasting for at least 4 consecutive days.
  • During this period, ≥3 of the following symptoms should be present to a significant degree:
    • Inflated self-esteem or grandiosity
    • Decreased requirement for sleep
    • Excessive talkativeness
    • Flight of ideas
    • Distractibility
    • Increase in goal-oriented activity or psychomotor agitation
    • Excessive involvement in activities that have a high potential for adverse outcomes such 
  • The episode is associated with a change in functioning that is atypical of the individual when asymptomatic and is observed by others.
  • The episode is not severe enough to cause marked deterioration in social or occupational functioning or to necessitate hospitalization. No psychotic episodes are seen.
  • The episode is not attributable to the use of a substance or to another medical condition.

Other options:

Option A: In mania, the symptoms should be present for at least 1 week and symptoms should be severe enough to cause marked impairment in social or occupational functioning. Psychotic features may also be seen in mania.

Option B: Dysthymia is also called a persistent depressive disorder. It is defined as a subaffective or subclinical depressive disorder that is insidious in onset and intermittent or persistent in the course. It lasts for at least 2 years. 

Option C: Cyclothymic disorder is a mild form of bipolar type II disorder. It is characterized by hypomania and mild depression.

questions.text: A male patient came to your clinic with complaints of excessive daytime sleepiness and tiredness throughout the day. He says that he gets sudden attacks of sleep while he talks to his clients at the office. Which of the following is unlikely to be found associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical vignette is suggestive of narcolepsy. Somniloquy is unlikely to be found associated with this condition.

Somniloquy is the unconscious speech during sleep. It may accompany other sleep disorders like night terror and sleepwalking.

Narcolepsy is marked by sleep attacks leading to 10-20 minutes of sleep. After this, the patient feels refreshed but remains tired throughout the rest of the day. It can happen at inappropriate times such as while working, eating, talking, or driving. The onset is usually between the ages of 10-20 years, after which it persists for life.

Cataplexy (sudden muscle weakness), hypnopompic (hallucinations upon awakening), or hypnagogic (hallucinations at the onset of sleep) hallucinations are associated features. Sleep paralysis may also be seen, in which the patient upon awakening will be unable to move his muscles.

A polysomnogram and multiple sleep latency tests are done to diagnose the condition. Modafinil, methylphenidate, and venlafaxine are the drugs used in the management.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman comes for a follow-up, 1 week after her first child was born. Her husband reports that his wife appears uninterested in taking care of the baby, has sudden crying outbursts and seems sad for no reason for the last 2 days. Her sleep is disturbed and she feels fatigued. She is able to carry out the daily chores and enjoys watching television like before. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient has mild depressive symptoms within the first week of delivery. So the most likely diagnosis is postpartum blues.

Postpartum blues, also called maternity blues, typically develop within one week of delivery, usually on the fourth or fifth postpartum day. The affected mothers are emotionally labile and the symptoms include changes in mood, sudden crying outbursts, and a lack of interest in the baby. They may also have insomnia, anxiety, poor concentration, and irritability.

These feelings have been ascribed to rapid changes in women's hormonal levels, the stress of childbirth, and the awareness of the increased responsibility that motherhood brings. This usually resolves spontaneously within 10-14 days. 

Management involves reassurance, education, and support. The patient must be followed-up and assessed for the possible development of a major depressive disorder.

Other options:

Option B: Symptoms should persist for >2 weeks to make the diagnosis of post-partum depression. A minimum of 5 symptoms of major depressive disorder i.e. impaired sleep, interest, guilt, energy, concentration, appetite, psychomotor activity, and suicidal ideation must be present. This patient is able to do her daily chores, enjoys watching TV, has a good appetite, and does not have guilt or suicidal ideation. Although this patient has disturbed sleep and fatigue, these are common physiological postpartum findings.

Option C: Post-partum psychosis is a psychiatric emergency and usually has a mean time of onset is 2-3 weeks postpartum. The predominant symptoms are hallucinations, delusions, suicidal thoughts, and thoughts of harming the baby. The onset of psychotic symptoms is usually preceded by signs such as insomnia, restlessness, labile mood, and agitation. Lithium, often in combina­tion with an antidepressant, is the treatment of choice.

Option D: Episodes of delirium in the postpartum period are characterized by a fluctuating level of awareness or attention. In this patient, there is no altered sense of awareness.

Note:  Zuranolone is the first-ever oral drug to be approved specifically for the treatment of postpartum depression. It is a neuroactive steroid that enhances the action of GABA in the brain and regulates mood.

questions.text:
While taking a sleep history from a patient in the psychiatric OPD, you notice she uses the word "torangle" when referring to her bed. She replies that she sleeps on the floor instead of her bed when you asked if she had any trouble sleeping lately. She is concerned about the details of her bedside table and lighting when she was asked how her sleep routine was. Which of the following thought disorders are seen in her?
  1. Neologism
  2. Perseveration
  3. Clang association
  4. Circumstantiality
  5. Tangentiality
  6. Derailment
questions.solution:
The thought disorders seen in her are neologism - making up a new word like 'torangle', circumstantiality - concerned about the details of the bedside table and lighting when asked about her sleep routine and tangentiality - mentions that she sleeps on the floor and not on the bed when asked if there is any difficulty falling asleep.

Neologism: The patient makes up a new word or condensed combination of several words, that is not a true word and is not readily understandable.

Example:
Doctor: "How are you feeling today?"
Patient: "I am feeling glaberfest"

Circumstantiality: The patient includes irrelevant details and goes on talking in a roundabout manner, but their thought ultimately reaches the answer

Example:
Doctor: "How did you get that bruise?"
Patient: "I woke up and had a cup of coffee, read the newspaper and went for a walk. It was a wonderful day in the park. I returned home and watched the TV. I took a nap in the afternoon after lunch. I slipped and fell in the bathroom. The fall gave me this bruise."

Tangentiality: The patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic but does not answer the question exactly. The speech moves away from the actual answer.

Example:
Doctor: "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?"
Patient: "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa"

Neologisms and tangentiality are disorders of form of thought while circumstantiality is a disorder of tempo, under stream of thought.

Related Pearl: Classification of disorders of thought

Related Pearl: Disorders of thought and perception

DISORDERS OF THOUGHT

DISORDER OF STREAM OF THOUGHT

(A) Disorder of tempo

(i) Flight of Ideas

Continuous flow of rapid speech that jumps from topic to topic

  • "I like mangoes, the weather is nice, India is great"

(ii) Retardation of thinking

Slow speed of speech and a prolonged latent period before a response

  • "I went to the market (pause)......... the shop was closed"

(iii) Circumstantialities

Inclusion of irrelevant details and going on in a roundabout manner, but their thought ultimately reaches the answer

  • Doctor: "How did you get that bruise?"

  • Patient: "I woke up and had a cup of coffee, read the newspaper and went for a walk. It was a wonderful day in the park. I returned home and watched the TV. I took a nap in the afternoon after lunch. I slipped and fell in the bathroom. The fall gave me this bruise."

(iv) Clang associations

Jumping from one word to another irrelevant rhyming word

  • I am Sam...I like jam...I travel in a tram"

(B) Disorder of continuity

(i) Perseveration

Repetition of out of context words, phrases, or ideas beyond the point of relevance.

  • Q1. What's your name?: "Rahul"

  • Q2. Where are you from?: "Rahul"

  • Q3. How old are you?: "Rahul"

(ii) Thought blocking

A sudden disruption of thought or a break in the flow of ideas

  • "I went to the market (extreme silence)...................."

DISORDER OF FORM OF THOUGHT

(i) Tangentiality

In response to a question, the patient gives a reply that is appropriate to the general topic but does not answer the question exactly. The speech moves away from the actual answer.

  • Doctor: "Have you had any trouble sleeping lately?"
  • Patient: "I usually sleep in my bed, but now I'm sleeping on the sofa"

(ii) Derailment

A breakdown in both the logical connection between ideas and the overall sense of goal-directedness. The words make sentences, but the sentences do not make sense.

  • "Some people just don't understand why I had breakfast in America during the first world war"

(iii) Neologisms

Bringing in new words that do not exist.

  • The world is not 'gooder' for people like me"

(iv) Desultory thoughts

Speech is grammatically correct, however, sudden unrelated ideas force their way in from time to time.

  • My actual problem is that the people never understand me and my stomach feels like an empty bucket"

(v) Word salad

Using a mixture of unintelligible meaningless words and sentences

  • Tree bus rain food home car tiger"

DISORDER OF POSSESSION OF THOUGHT
A. Thought alienation

(i) Thought insertion

Thoughts are being inserted into the patient's mind and they recognize them as being foreign and coming from without any stimulus

  • "I have repeated thoughts of killing my neighbors and I believe aliens are putting these ideas into my head at night"

(ii) Thought withdrawal

Delusion that someone or something is removing from one's mind and the patient has no power over this.

  • "Lately, I am losing all my memories and I believe that the 'government agents' are stealing them when I go to sleep"

(iii) Thought broadcasting

Belief that one's thoughts are quietly escaping from one's mind and that other people might be able to access them and hear or see them.

  • "I believe my exact thoughts appear on the TV and the internet and I think I can broadcast them globally" 

(iv) Thought echo

Patient hears the 'echo' of his own thoughts in the form of a voice after he has made the thought.

  • "I thought of making a sandwich in the morning and surprisingly a voice, from nowhere, told me to make a sandwich out loud" 

 B. Obsessions and Compulsions

1. Obsessions

Recurrent and persistent thoughts, impulses. or images that cause distress to oneself.

  • Fear of dirt or contamination
  • Fear of becoming ill
  • Constant thoughts of a certain number
  • Need for symmetry or exactness
  • Worry about whether something has been done "right"
  • Forbidden sexual or religious thoughts

2. Compulsions

Repetitive behaviors or actions that the person feels driven to perform in response to an obsession

  • Washing hands
  • Blinking eyes
  • Counting items, such as currency
  • Checking to see if doors are locked
  • Arranging items in a certain way
  • Requiring constant approval from people around them

 
 DISORDER OF CONTENT OF THOUGHT

(i) Phobias

Persistent fear of an object or situation, typically disproportional to the actual danger posed, in which the sufferer goes to great lengths in avoiding it

  • Arachnophobia - fear of spider
  • Barophobia - fear of gravity
  • Cynophobia - fear of dogs
  • Hemophobia - fear of blood
  • Nosocomephobia - fear of hospitals

(ii) Religious preoccupations

Thoughts involving religious themes or subject matter.

  • "I get instructions from God on how to make my country great"

(iii) Ideas of hopelessness

Thoughts of complete despair where the patient strongly believes that the circumstances will never get better for him.

  • "I am never going to pass my final exams, no matter how hard I study"

(iv) Antisocial urges

Thoughts of indulging in some behaviors or actions that harm or lack consideration for the well being of others.

  • "I have these urges to go rob a bank or blackmail my neighbors for their money"

(v) Delusions

False beliefs that are strongly held and unchangeable in the face of refuting evidence and that are not consistent with the person's educational, social and cultural background.

The three main criteria for a belief to be considered a delusion are:

  • Certainty (held with complete confidence)
  • Incorrigibility (not changeable by proof to the contrary)
  • Impossibility or falsity of content (implausible, bizarre or patently untrue)
 DISORDERS OF PERCEPTIONS

  • Illusion: Misinterpretation of real external stimuli.

  • Hallucination: False sensory perception, externally.

  • Pseudohallucination: False sensory perception from within and having an insight.

  • Depersonalization: Feeling as if one is disconnected from reality, feeling detached from one's own thoughts and one's own physical body.

    "I sometimes drift into a dream-like state where I lose contact with my own self"

  • Derealization: Alteration in the perception or experience of the external world so that it seems unreal.

    "The world and everything around is nothing but just a dream"

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy has been brought with complaints of thumb sucking for the last 2 months. He has a 3-month-old brother who was born preterm and is in the NICU. His parents spend a lot of time with him in the hospital. Which of the following defense mechanisms is he exhibiting?
questions.solution:
This patient's behaviour of thumb sucking is a behaviour exhibited by neonates and disappears by 5 years of age. Reverting back to behaviours from a previous developmental stage age is regression.

Regression occurs as a method to deal with the anxieties associated with conflict. In this case, it is the likely lack of attention paid by the parents to the patient due to them spending time with his sick sibling. The condition is managed by offering psychotherapy to the child and encouraging the parents to spend more time with him.

Related Pearl: Defense mechanisms

Narcissistic-psychotic defenses

Denial: Used to avoid becoming aware of some painful aspects of reality.

  • Eg: I know I do not have cancer.

Distortion: Grossly reshaping the experience of external reality to suit inner needs.

  • Eg: I possess special powers and abilities and am superior to others.

Projection (psychotic): Attributing your own wishes, thoughts, or feelings onto someone else.

  • Eg: I’m sure my wife is cheating on me.

Splitting: External objects are divided into all good or all bad.

  • Eg: The morning staff is perfect, the evening staff is terrible.

 

Immature defenses

Acting out: Behavioral or emotional outburst.

  • Eg: My 10-year-old started getting into trouble right after his mother and I got divorced.

Blocking: Temporary block in thinking.

  • Eg: I have known him for years but can never seem to remember his name.

Hypochondriasis: A defense style in which people say that no one understands their pain.

  • Eg: No one understands the depth of my pain.

Introjection: Features of the external world are taken and made part of the self.

  • Eg: The resident physician dresses like the attending whom he admires.

Passive-aggressive behavior: Aggressive intent is cloaked by a passive method.

  • Eg: Procrastinating at work for not getting the promotion.

Projection (non-psychotic): Unwanted feelings are displaced onto another person.

  • Eg: A man who has been unfaithful to his wife but accuses his wife of cheating on him.

Regression: Return to an earlier stage of development, most immature.

  • Eg: Ever since my divorce, my 5-year-old has begun to wet the bed.

Schizoid fantasy: Tendency to retreat into fantasy in order to resolve inner and outer conflicts.

  • Eg: Adolescents day dreaming on pornographic materials.

Somatization: Psychic derivatives are converted into bodily symptoms.

  • Eg: Just thinking of the exam I get butterflies in my stomach.

 

Neurotic defenses

Externalization: Perceiving one’s personality, impulses, moods and attitudes in the external world.

  • Eg: An argumentative person perceives the doctor as argumentative whilst believing himself to be blameless.

Displacement: Shifting emotions about one object/ individual onto another object/ individual.

  • Eg: Getting angry at your parents because you had a bad day at work.

Inhibition: conscious or unconscious constraint of a process or behavior.

  • Eg: A desire to eat dessert versus the desire to lose weight.

Intellectualization: Excessive use of intellectual processes to avoid affective expression or experience.

  • Eg: It is interesting to note the specific skin lesions which seem to arise as a consequence of my end-stage disease.

Isolation: Separation of an idea from the affect that accompanies it.

  • Eg: As she arrived at the station to identify the body, she appeared to show no emotion.

Rationalization: Rational explanations are used to justify unacceptable attitudes, beliefs, or behaviors.

  • Eg: I did not pass the test because it was harder this year than ever before.

Reaction formation: An unacceptable impulse is transformed into its opposite; results in the formation of character traits.

  • Eg: Listen to him tell his family he was not afraid when I saw him crying.

Repression: An idea or feeling is withheld from consciousness; unconscious forgetting.

  • Eg: I do not remember having had a dog.

Sexualization: Endowing an object or function with sexual significance.

Undoing: Acting out the reverse of unacceptable behavior; consists of an act.

  • Eg: I need to wash my hands whenever I have these thoughts.

Retroflexion: Self-destruction due to rage.

  • Eg: A person cutting his wrist because he is angry with himself.

 

Mature defenses

Altruism: Getting pleasure from giving to others what the individual would have liked to receive.

  • Eg:  A former alcoholic funding a rehabilitation center.

Anticipation: Realistically planning or anticipating future inner discomfort.

  • Eg: Moderate amount of anxiety before surgery.

Asceticism: Gratification derived from renunciation.

Humor: Permits the expression of feelings and thoughts without personal discomfort.

  • Eg: Before execution, firing squad leader offers the man a cigarette. He replies "no thanks I'm trying to quit".

Sublimation: Impulse gratification has been achieved, but the aim or object has been changed from unacceptable to acceptable; allows instincts to be channeled. Most mature of the defenses.

  • Eg: Jack the Ripper becomes a surgeon.

Suppression: Conscious forgetting. The only conscious defense mechanism.

  • Eg: I would rather talk about my operation after the party is over.

questions.text: The period between a thought and its verbal expression is increased in_______________ and decreased in ________________ ?
questions.solution:
The period between a thought and its verbal expression is called thought latency and is increased in schizophrenia and decreased in mania.

Blocking: Abrupt interruption in the train of thought, and after a brief pause, the person indicates no recall of what was being said or was going to be said (also known as thought deprivation or increased thought latency). Seen in schizophrenia and severe anxiety.

Pressured speech: Increase in the amount of spontaneous speech - rapid, loud, accelerated speech. Seen in mania.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man visits a psychiatrist. He says that he has a feeling that his surroundings are dreamlike, lifeless, unreal, and fictitious. He explains that he feels detached from his surroundings. His reality testing remains intact, and he does not abuse any drugs. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A sense of dreamlike, lifeless, unreal, and fictitious surroundings in a person who does not abuse drugs, along with intact reality testing, is suggestive of a diagnosis of derealisation disorder.

Derealisation is a condition characterised by a sense of unreality or feeling detached from one's surroundings. Individuals experiencing derealisation may describe a perception of the external world as lacking clarity and emotional depth, similar to being in a dream-like state or feeling emotionally numb.

Derealisation is frequently observed in patients with seizures and migraines. Additionally, it can occur as a result of using psychedelic drugs, particularly marijuana, lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD), and mescaline. Less commonly, derealisation can also occur as a side effect of certain medications, including anticholinergic agents.

Since depersonalisation and derealisation disorders have similar presentations, DSM-V lists the following criteria to diagnose them:

  • The presence of persistent or recurrent experiences of depersonalisation, derealisation, or both.
  • Intact reality testing during the episodes.
  • The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.
  • The disturbance is not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, medication) or another medical condition(e.g., seizures). 
  • The disturbance is not better explained by another mental disorder, such as schizophrenia, panic disorder, major depressive disorder, acute stress disorder, posttraumatic stress disorder, or another dissociative disorder.

Related Pearl: Dissociative Disorders

DSM-5 Classification and characteristics of dissociative disorders:

Dissociative disorder
Characteristic features

Dissociative amnesia:

Failure to remember important information about oneself after a stressful event.

Amnesia usually resolves in minutes or days but may last years. Retrograde amnesia > antegrade amnesia

Dissociative fugue:

Amnesia combined with sudden wandering from home after a stressful event.

Adoption of a different identity. The patient denies memory loss during the fugue state.

Dissociative identity disorder:

Previously called multiple personality disorder.

At least two distinct personalities (“alters”) in an individual.

More common in women (particularly those sexually abused in childhood)

In a forensic setting (Eg: jail), malingering and alcohol abuse must be considered and excluded

Depersonalization disorder:

Recurrent, persistent feelings of detachment from one’s own body, the social situation, or the environment (derealisation) when stressed.

 Understanding that these perceptions are only feelings, i.e., normal reality testing.

Dissociative disorder not otherwise specified:

Dissociate symptom (Eg: trance-like state, memory loss) in - 
  • Persons exposed to intense coercive persuasion (Eg: brainwashing)
  • Indigenous to particular locations or cultures (Eg: Amok in Indonesia)
 

ICD-11 classifies Dissociative Disorders as:

  • Dissociative Identity Disorder
  • Partial Dissociative Identity Disorder
  • Depersonalization-Derealization disorder
  • Dissociative Amnesia
  • Trance Disorder
  • Possession Trance Disorder
  • Dissociative Neurological symptom disorder
  • Secondary Dissociative syndrome

questions.text: A young male patient has been on antipsychotics for many months. However, recently, he has had focal perioral tremors of the choreoathetoid type. The tongue is spared. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis is Rabbit syndrome.

Extrapyramidal symptoms like akathasia, acute dystonia, tardive dyskinesia, and Rabbit syndrome are side effects of antipsychotics.

Rabbit syndrome is an antipsychotic-induced rhythmic motion of the mouth/lips resembling the chewing movements of a rabbit.  The movement consists of a vertical-only motion at about 5Hz, with no involvement of the tongue.It occurs months to years after intake of antipsychotics. 

Other options

Options B: Tardive Dyskinesia is involuntary movements of the tongue, lips, face, trunk, and extremities that occur in patients treated with long-term dopaminergic antagonist medications. It occurs months to years after intake of antipsychotics. 

Option C: Akathisia consists of motor restlessness accompanied by subjective feelings of inner tension and discomfort referable chiefly to the limbs. It occurs within 5-60 days of intake of antipsychotics. 

Option D: Acute dystonia is characterised by spasms of the muscles of the tongue, face, neck and back. It occurs within 1-5 days of intake of antipsychotics. 

Amongst extrapyramidal symptoms of antipsychotics, acute muscular dystonia is the earliest appearing symptom and akathisia is the most common one.

questions.text: A 19-year-old female patient comes to the OPD with complaints of weakness, amenorrhea, and fatigue.  Upon eliciting a history, she reveals that she is always worried about gaining weight. Her mother complains that she does not eat well. Her BMI is 15.8 kg/m². Laboratory findings in this patient will show which of the following?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of anorexia nervosa. Hypersecretion of corticotrophin-releasing hormone is seen in a patient with anorexia nervosa.

Anorexia nervosa is a type of eating disorder in which the patient has intense fear of becoming fat. This fear leads to restriction of calorie intake resulting in significantly reduced body weight. The patient does not understand the seriousness of the reduced body weight and continues to restrict food intake. Some patients might also have history of self-induced vomiting, misuse of laxatives, diuretics, or enemas. Laboratory investigations of these patients might show leukopenia with relative lymphocytosis, hypokalemic alkalosis, hypoglycemia, elevated serum salivary amylase levels, hypercholesterolemia, amenorrhea, mild hypothyroidism, and hypersecretion of corticotrophin-releasing hormone.

Anorexia nervosa is a type of eating disorder that is characterized by self-induced starvation to a significant degree, drive for thinness or a morbid fear of fatness, and the presence of medical signs and symptoms resulting from starvation.

Investigations in anorexia nervosa:

  • Complete blood count: Leukopenia with a relative lymphocytosis
  • Serum electrolyte: Hypokalemic alkalosis (Purging)
  • Fasting serum glucose: Often low (emaciated phase) (Option D)
  • Serum salivary amylase: Often elevated (if the patient is vomiting)
  • ECG: ST segment and T-wave changes (secondary to electrolyte disturbances)
  • Hypotension and bradycardia
  • High serum cholesterol level (Option A)
  • Endocrine changes (caused by the underweight):
    • Amenorrhea
    • Hypothyroidism (Option B)
    • Hypersecretion of corticotrophin-releasing hormone
